A wonderful illustration of the aphorism, "Power corrupts, absolute power corrupts absolutely." A must read for anyone naive enough to believe Marxism still has relevance.

Where, oh where is the 21st century's Orwell? The man is insightful, bold, and spot on. Although this book is taught as a primer in High Schools across America (probably for its size and the obviousness of its satirical allegory of Soviet totalitarianism). I loved it, and it still charms, as much as an allegory about totalitarianism can charm really.

This wasn't my first time reading Animal Farm, but it was definitely the most rewarding read through it I've ever done. There are two reasons for this: the first is that I was reading it with one of my students, who emigrated from a communist country for political reasons, and secondly it's the first time I've read anything by Orwell since the beginning of the "War On Terror". Both of these conspired to create a sense of urgency to the reading, and also helped to illustrate exactly how relevant Orwell still is today. While 1984 is entirely tied to totalitarian regimes, Animal Farm shows how they come about - through a combination of willful political ignorance by the masses, a government that wishes to maintain control by using a scapegoat villain who is blamed for all of the country's woes. This is the kind of book that needs to be read by everyone in a democratic government as a warning - unfortunately, it's also too often ignored to our peril.

I had to read this over the summer for an Honors Government class. I didnt mind it, since it was so short, but I didnt like it much either. I read it AFTER reading 1984. Big mistake. This is practically a summary of 1984, even though it was written before it. If you want to read a much much much better version of this story, just skip it and move on to the Orwell's real telling of this story, 1984.
A scathing indictment of Stalinism wrapped in the charming trappings of a fable, Animal Farm is a concise masterpiece and one of the best books you can read in a single sitting.

A través de la fábula del la granja de los Jones, Orwell realiza una sátira del estalinismo, y una crítica y análisis de cómo el poder genera corrupción. Es una denuncia contra todo tipo de totalitarismo.

I read this book three times in middle school and high school, and only two of those times was I required to. I read it again this year and it was just as awesome as I remember. It is amazing how this story can act as a history lesson and a contemporary parable at the same time. I think that it has always been topical and always will.This particular edition is a treat, too, because of the illustrations by Ralph Steadman... The spilling ink and motion of the art captures well the grotesqueness of the pigs and the horror of the tale.

Animal Farm is literary social commentary at its best. An engaging allegory reminding one that power corrupts and absolute power corrupts absolutely. Accessible and thought-provoking; great for discussion groups.
Great book to introduce students to the role, function, and dangers of government. Great writing and characters that still live on in the American lexicon.

Animal farm: A love story. Well, not exactly, but an interesting take on humanity were it in the animal form. Still nutty? Maybe, but this book uses allegory to show one of the biggest political struggles of the twentieth century. It's not for everyone, but, when in doubt, remember: it's just a story.

This, of course, is Orwell's farm-set satire of the Russian Revolution. It's one of my favorites and I find it more readable than 1984 if not a superior work. This "50th Anniversary edition" is illustrated by Ralph Steadman, which is another plus in my book. His frenzied style fits with the text nicely. Also included are Orwell's Proposed Preface (a scathing comment on the publishing industry's practice of hushed up censorship) and his Preface to the Ukranian Edition.

Reading Orwell always makes my blood boil. Which, on occasion, is a good thing. Halfway through Animal Farm I was almost incoherent with rage - which, I am sure, was Orwell's intent. The man is a master. I felt the same way about Nineteen Eighty-Four; for a long time I hated that book as it was the first thing I'd read that didn't have a happy ending, and I felt betrayed. Now of course I'm old and wise enough to realise that for both books, their endings are the only natural and true ones that can follow from the material. Orwell's worlds are bleak and abhorrent, but he paints the terrifying picture of how similar they are to our own, if we do not take care to avoid that easy path to our own destruction, one seemingly reasonable step at a time.

George Orwell's Animal Farm is quite deservedly a classic, and for many reasons. I first encountered in at high school, in 1970, when I was 14 years old and in 2nd form. I was pretty naive at the time, and Animal Farm was my first real introduction to the harsh realities of life and that thing called 'politics' which, as the book shows, is so much driven by greed and corruption. Animal Farm was a good book for school because it was presented as a simple fable which anyone could understand, plot wise that is. As regards the deeper meaning and relationship with the past and present, well I know it was discussed at school, but a lot of that understanding would come with time and maturity. Comprehension of the book was assisted by the cartoon film version, all of which had an undoubted influence on my 12 year old brain. The book is timeless, because the issues discussed have not gone away. The lesson of history is not that we learn from our mistakes, but rather, that we learn how to improve upon and repeat our so-called mistakes. Greed and corruption is rife in our society like never before, and dutifully hidden under a blanket of spin. The story of the pigs and the farm animals is oft repeated in various cgi digital creations, though with much of the politics and the punch removed. For Orwell's story is dark, bleak and real, and therefore not really the stuff of kids entertainment. It is time for a remake of Animal Farm, in this post 9/11 Coalition of the Willing environment, though hopefully this time it won't be funded by the CIA and its ending changed.

i read this book when i was in college for a book report. i found it good to my surprise. even if it was written several years ago, i still find it very much relevant to our present situation. it's politically relevant and very much describes the "animals" in the government. Ü
A classic tale of politics from a barnyard perspective. The farm setting removes some of the 'human' element and allows Orwell to focus on politics and rhetoric.
i had to read this book twicethe first time i HATED itthe 2nd time i didnt like it much eitheri dont reccomend it much

Talking pigs? Chickens with a totalitarian mindset? Orwell uses everyone's favorite farm animals to depict the struggle for freedom reflecting the time period of this book. A book I read when I was way too young, but still stands out for me today.
Excellent - If anyone hasn't read this, you should read it as soon as possible..! It's a classic that everyone who reads, knows! Great fun to read.
Reading this as an adult is so different to when I read it in class aged 11. We didn't understand the real complexities in it then, we thought it was just an animal story!
Classic read!
A classic that I have read many, many times.

I don't think this book is as great as everyone else does. It is a satire on Communism, wherein the animals on a farm drive out their human exploiters in a Marxist revolution, only to have the pigs gradually become the new masters, just like the humans they drove out. Everyone seems to think this book is a denuciation of communism, but it is not. The ideal of communism is never challenged, just its corruption by the ambitious pigs. In other words, it's a satire on Stalinism. I think that Orwell's critique of totalitarianism in 1984 is much, much better than that in Animal Farm.

This was definitely an interesting read, if it wasn't much of a page-turner. I think it would be a great discussion book for my high school students: which animal would you want on your side in case of battle? What rulers would you compare Napolean to? What part of the system did Squealer represent? Why is education important in a democracy?

You can't complain about a book that gets right to the point and says all that need be said in 128 pages. Not a moment is wasted in unecessary exposition or attempts at being more "literary."It is well written and deserves its reputation as one of the great English language novels. I know all about it being a statement against totalitarianism, but I'm not smart enough to discuss all that. It works just as well as a fairy tale that exposes the problems of power and greed.
delightful. i just saw an illustrated version at borders the other day. perfect to read to small children so that they don't grow up to be fascists.

Plot: straightforward, with no side-plots branching off. It mostly serves as a backdrop for the character-driven story. Characters: aside from some exceptions, characterization isn't done for individuals but for species, playing on common stereotypes. The cast is fairly large for a short novella, and yet there is plenty of time to draw the character traits. Much of it also relies on the reader recognizing who is being parodied and adding it to the picture.Style: simple and powerful writing, with great use of symbolism. The atmosphere becomes more and more suppressing, which reflects in the vocabulary chosen.Plus: Wonderfully implemented metaphors. Minus: Too short, and the end is somewhat dissatisfying. Summary: Must be read.
something like the russian revolution retold through the farm.

Too often overlooked as a simpler polemic than Orwell's "1984." I loved the book and its easy to read allegory. Its a great way to get into deeper political writings such as Marx without falling victim to an idealistic reading. Its small and good for high school students, but I would also recommend rereading it later especially after reading Marx or Engels.
A good book for a 5th-8th grade audience as long as they're at least somewhat aware of the political allegories in it.

I read this the first time when I was in 5th grade, then read it several more times before finishing high-school. We all know the story of the farm animals rising up against their oppressor. Ultimately, though, this is a story of how power corrupts. I will never forget the line "...but some are more equal than others."

The Western literary canon sometimes seems a bit short of politicalparables involving animals. Thank god for George Orwell fillingthat otherwise empty niche. One of what you might call the "AmericanHigh School Classic" thanks to it's easily digestable themes and colorcoded characters, it's popularity hardly draws away from the fact thatit is a chilling political fable. Basically detailing a communistuprising on a small English farm, it matches Orwell's hatred of theSoviets with his hatred of totalitarianism in general, making for aquick, invigorating read.(This review originally appeared on zombieunderground.net)
I didn't like the ending, but overall, it's a good satire of Soviet Russia. I found it much more enjoyable than 1984.

Sátira del estalinismo, que surgida de la pluma de un ex-comunista como Orwell gana en credibilidad.Esta novela defiende como ninguna la tesis de que el poder corrompe, y que el poder absoluto corrompe absolutamente.Como su gran éxito 1984 nos encontramos con un alegato contra el autoritarismo que debería leer todo el mundo.
Not quite as good as 1984 but still a very good book. I always get upset when the horse dies, which is probably why I rate it behind 1984.

An eighth grade force-read. If you can't tell, I despised my eighth grade English teacher, her class, the school district, and its dumbed-down curriculum. In short, my hatred of her seeped into this book, and I really should read it again before making any solid decision about it.

I had to read this book for school and found myself really enjoying it. If you read this book, you must read it in an analytical way rather than just reading it as a story about animals. It's a great read if you want to learn about the Russian Revolution.

A good classic, George Orwell presents what Communism can do to society. The end result? The leaders of the new society become exactly like their enemy. It is the journey there that is so interesting.

George Orwell's classic allegory about what happens when the animals take over the farm, a vivid and humorously dead-on portrait of a Communist takeover. Written in 1945, it remains as valid and enthralling as ever. Any book that gives rise to the popular quote "All animals are equal, but some are more equal than others" has much to recommend it.

A better satire on authoritarianism has perhaps not been written. Its simplicity is such that it can be enjoyed by children and adults alike, though enjoyed wont be quite the right word for adults, but enjoy we do, nevertheless. Though generally known as a satire on the Russian revolution and the ideals it finally betrayed, today it can applied to a large variety of example and instances, something that perhaps Orwell himself foresaw as well, as he remarked that it is a protest against every form of authoritarianism, whether right or left. One need not know the history of the Russian revolution and its aftermath to understand the implications in the book and the basic foundation of the book is something we can all relate to, relate to what Kafka said about revolutions that all revolutions come and leave a bureaucracy behind. Even if the reader does not know who “Major” or “Snowball” is portrayed on, they can relate to them easily, as they can relate easily to “Boxer”, the unknown idealistic man or woman who is ultimately sacrificed as a pawn by leaders who ultimately begin to become the men they have overthrown. In the end perhaps, it’s a dark book but in a vein that is humorous even when it’s immensely ironic.It’s a timeless book because it deals with an idea that is inherent with human nature and that is something that has little changed in all of human history.
Timeless, wonderful, wry.

Although i had a fair idea of what was going to happen before i read the book, some things still came as a shock whilst reading it. Also i hardly put this book down, a great read, i felt that this was an example of a nice ideal destoryed by the inequities of those involved, much like the part of history that it satires.
I read this book in high school as a high school assignment and found it disturbing then. It might be more relavent now. This is a must read.

After having this book on my shelf for more than 10 years, I finally read it. And boy am I glad I decided to pick it up. It's by far the best allegory I have ever read. Explaining and criticizing communism using pigs and other farm animals is simply brilliant. And that it's short and to the point, just adds to Orwell's genius. A true masterpiece.

This novella takes the saying short and sweet to a whole new level. It gets across it's meaning consisely and without dallying with other topics that have nothing to do with the subject at hand. Not to mention that it's a masterful satyre that pokes fun at Communism, and with farm animals no less! It's an ideal book for many ages, as the older ideas don't come across to the younger age group and to them it can be little more than a tale of talking animals doing great things, whereas older readers can quickly recognize the bigger message of the story.

A very well written allegorical tale about Russian politics. I didn't enjoy this when I read it as a bored 12 year old but I appreciate it a lot more now. 4 stars because it's hard to ignore first impressions, but also because it is genuinely a great book.
Wonderful book! One of the best books I had to read during my sophomore year in high school.

A book caomparing communists to animals on a farm. It is very well written with phrases and pages that use emphasis on big events. The whole point of the story isn't actually the story, but showing all the events that lead from beginnind to end, with nothing that can be spared. Not for a light reader, although it is compparitivly short, it is quite serious. I don't think it's one of those book sthat can make you cry, mainly because animal tragedy isn't as sad as human tragedy. The book is a satire also, so you dont want to cry. I felt like I half wanted to laugh, but couldn't cause it is pretty much the communist government. Which takes all the silliness out of it and puts it in a point of view that anyone can understand. You can trick your children in to thinking it's a fantasy-happy story about animals...on a farm. Boy won't they be in for a surprise.

I first read this book in high school, and absolutely loved it. Sadly, the experience was somewhat tainted by the majority of my classmates missing the point entirely. They didn't seem to understand why, at their age, they were being made to read a story about talking animals. They missed out on a great book. Animal Farm is on my list of books I think everyone needs to read, at least once in their life. The ending gives me a wonderfully disturbed, unsettled feeling (isn't it great when a book can affect you like that?), and its message is just as relevant today as it was when it was first published.

I read this book the year before it was actually assigned to me because I had come across it in the library and talking animals looked interesting. When the book was assigned to us, a friend asked me what it was about. "Communist pigs," I replied.While it has the eerie, almost prophetic feel of "1984", it's much easier to read. I think it's a book any middle or high school student could read and comprehend, but discussions about real world application of the story may be needed. There are simply some things you don't truly appreciate until you've lived in the adult world, and this book deals with a lot of them.

One of the classics of 20th Century literature, this dystopian 'fairy-tale' is an allegory that tells us much more about humans and their capacity for dictatorship than it does about any farm.It must be remembered that this book was published for the first time sixty years ago - the allegory may be bordering on the blatantly obvious at times, but this is a post-Soviet age where we are much more aware of the dangers of deluded dictatorships where the will of the people is mangled into the privelege for the few. However, it is still highly relevant - just think North Korea.

I read this book a few years ago and was not nearly as affected by it as I was when I started it for the first time at age 15, and was so overcome by outrage I couldn't finish it. It may have led directly to my current Libertarian leanings :)

It's hard to write about Animal Farm without comparing it to 1984, so that's what I'm going to do. Especially because of the two, I find Animal Farm to be the better novel.Though both have their fair share of iconic imagery and allegory, on the whole I think that Animal Farm is Orwell's better work. To begin with, it's a more well constructed story and consequently an easier read. Whereas 1984 simply paints a picture of a dystopia, Animal Farm shows how a dystopia comes to be - how the noble ideals that began the revolution get perverted, and the utopian dream is lost. It's more fantastical setting involving farm animals enhances it as an allegory, as opposed to 1984 which originally put me off because of the poorly conceived science fictional elements.
When I first started teaching, this novel was pretty standard for freshman English. While it is a good teaching novel, I'm not particularly fond of it myself.

Este é o primeiro grande sucesso alcançado pelo escritor britânico George Orwell, a cinco anos de sua morte. O livro denuncia o totalitarismo político do ditador soviético Josef Stalin, interpretado nesta fábula como um traidor da causa bolchevista. Os animais de uma fazenda (no título original em inglês, "Animal Farm", não há a menção de revolta implícita na versão brasileira do título), fartos da dominação humana, rebelam-se em grande estilo, mas os propósitos de sua revolução são desvirtuados. George Orwell é realista, cirúrgico, exato, e sua escrita, contundente, um exemplar literário que ambiciona ao manifesto. -- por Rosane Pavam

Amazon.comSince its publication in 1946, George Orwell's fable of a workers' revolution gone wrong has rivaled Hemingway's The Old Man and the Sea as the Shortest Serious Novel It's OK to Write a Book Report About. (The latter is three pages longer and less fun to read.) Fueled by Orwell's intense disillusionment with Soviet Communism, Animal Farm is a nearly perfect piece of writing, both an engaging story and an allegory that actually works. When the downtrodden beasts of Manor Farm oust their drunken human master and take over management of the land, all are awash in collectivist zeal. Everyone willingly works overtime, productivity soars, and for one brief, glorious season, every belly is full. The animals' Seven Commandment credo is painted in big white letters on the barn. All animals are equal. No animal shall drink alcohol, wear clothes, sleep in a bed, or kill a fellow four-footed creature. Those that go upon four legs or wings are friends and the two-legged are, by definition, the enemy. Too soon, however, the pigs, who have styled themselves leaders by virtue of their intelligence, succumb to the temptations of privilege and power. "We pigs are brainworkers. The whole management and organisation of the farm depend on us. Day and night, we are watching over your welfare. It is for your sake that we drink that milk and eat those apples." While this swinish brotherhood sells out the revolution, cynically editing the Seven Commandments to excuse their violence and greed, the common animals are once again left hungry and exhausted, no better off than in the days when humans ran the farm. Satire Animal Farm may be, but it's a stony reader who remains unmoved when the stalwart workhorse, Boxer, having given his all to his comrades, is sold to the glue factory to buy booze for the pigs. Orwell's view of Communism is bleak indeed, but given the history of the Russian people since 1917, his pessimism has an air of prophecy. --Joyce Thompson--This review has been flagged by multiple users as abuse of the terms of service and is no longer displayed (show).
